Censorship is a tricky concept. It is a word that can ban music from stores, books from shelves, and movies from theaters. Katherine Paterson, an author, said that if all things reading or listening materials were removed, nothing would be left. I thoroughly agree with that statement. If someone finds one aspect of a work offensive, that does not qualify for the work to be banned or discarded. I believe offensive material should not be removed because of the following reasons: it suppresses the feelings of the author, nothing will be left on the shelves, and there is no defining line on what is or is not offensive. Now, I understand there is a vast amount of people who are against my position. I assure them that I understand those feelings. Some audiences feel that the removal of offensive material is good because it shields the ears of those who cannot handle the verbage or context. Others feel that sensitive audiences might not be comfortable with the text. In addtion, many people believe that exposing people to violent, risky, and material with dangerous habits will evoke the same behavior in young children. Though these are all valid opinions, they are not enough to automatically think that it is okay to throw it off the shelves. Contrary to the opinions of others, I believe one reason offensive material should be kept on the shelves because if it is not on the shelves, then the thoughts and feelings of the writer will be suppressed. For instance, the book 'To Kill a Mockingbird' was banned for a long time. Harper Lee's book, might have had some slurs we might find offensive today. However, that is the way people in that time spoke. Who are we to fault the people of the 1930s and 1960s for how that articulate words? By banning 'To Kill a Mockingbird' for the time frame that it was banned, generations were robbed of the powerful and beautiful meaning of the entire book. That meaning was that you cannot punish the innocent because they have done nothing wrong. The same for done for offensive book. That is one reason why I believe that should stay on the shelves. Next, works of literature and music should stay on the shelves because as Katherine Paterson said if everyone removes a book, '...then we have no books left on the shelf for any of us.' That is very true. Many books have been on the banned book list. For instance there is 'To Kill a Mockingbird,' 'Catcher in the Rye,' 'Beloved,' and the like. What book will be removed from the shelves next? Once society is relieved of all literature, the next step will be music. Look at the singer/songwriter Prince. He made some very sexually themed music. When people bought his records in the 1980s, they had to be covered or placed in brown papered bags. They might be considered censorship, but that is one step away from being banned. His record company refused to produce his music under his name because of the scandalous lyrics. Because of that, Prince has changes his name to an unpronouncable symbol. What will be next? Finally, my last reason for why offensive material should not be removed is because who is to say whether or not something is offensive? A novel or song might be pleasing to 100 people, but should it be extinguished from the record store or library because of one person? I do not think so. There are many words and concepts that have not be socially accepted of the centuries. However, those same appalling concepts have become accepted if not an uncommon habit. If that 'offensive material' is given time, it will become unoffensive in the years to come. For all the reasons I have stated, I do not agree with removing anything off the shelves because something finds it to unacceptable if not offensive. If everything is removed because of an opinion, the world of the arts will be no more. Then, we as people will wonder what will be left of us. We will be nothing more than a mass of narrow-minded and ignorant individuals who know nothing about books, music, magazines, movies, etc. Now, I pose that question to you: If all was deemed offensive material, what would be left?

Everyone has a different view of books. What one person thinks is bad, another might not. It goes the other way, too: What one person thinks is good, another might think is bad. There are thousands of libraries throughout the world, all filled with numerous books, magazines, music, movies, etc., for people of all ages to obtain. Some people think that materials in a library should be censored, while others think everything should be allowed to be there. I do not think materials at a library should be removed, or censored, because the materials would decrease, people would choose what to look at, and the material would help with research.  Materials at libraries should not be censored because the materials allowed at the libraries would decrease. Everyone has different opinions on what they think is appropriate or not. If one person were to decide a book was inappropriate and take it off the shelf, another person would have the right to take another book that they thought was inappropriate off the shelf as well. However, since everyone has different beliefs on what is appropriate and what is not, the books would rapidly decrease. The same would apply to the other items at the libraries such as magazines, movies, etc. Consequently, the range of resources would diminish significantly.  Another reason is because everyone has their own choice about what they want to look at in a library. A fifty-year-old man would not have the same interests as a thirteen-year-old girl, so if some materials were removed, there would not be as much of a variety to choose from. If there is little variety to choose from due to materials being censored, the amount of people using the library would decrease, causing the library to eventually get shut down from the lack of people using it. Ultimately, censorship would undermine the library's role as a public resource.  Lastly, materials at a library should not be censored because each and every item there could help with some kind of research. A child from high school could go to the library to look for a book to help research things for a report in one of their classes, or an elder woman could go to the library in search of a cookbook to research something new to make for her next home-cooked meal. Both people would need a material from the library to help them with their research, but if some materials at the library were removed, they might not be able to find something to help them. Therefore, limiting resources would hinder the pursuit of knowledge.  Materials at a library should not be censored because the materials would decrease, people would choose what to look at, and the material would help with research. Some people believe removing items at a library should be allowed, but I strongly disagree. There are many different materials in the libraries around the world today for people of all ages to come in contact with, and that is the way it should stay, allowing for a diverse and accessible collection for all.

Public libraries should not have to censor their books, movies, and music. We have the right to learn and expand our minds as we see fit. There are three main reasons why 'offensive' pieces should be allowed in public libraries. First, humans have been expressing themselves throughout history, resulting in too many pieces to eliminate. Second, opinions differ on what is 'offensive'. Third, people will encounter what you try to hide in the real world.  Throughout history, mankind has documented experiences, events, and ideas, including profanity, sexuality, death, and other potentially 'offensive' situations. Deleting these pieces would destroy a part of history, and there are simply too many to remove. Almost every art form contains some negative element. Removing them would leave very few books.  People have different opinions on what is bad. For example, on a band trip, a movie had to be turned off because one parent found it inappropriate, while others saw nothing wrong with it. The same applies to books and music; it depends on personal views.  People will experience what you are trying to hide regardless. If you remove it from the library, they will hear about it on the news, radio, in restaurants, or schools. Removing pieces from the library is ultimately useless. For example, people want to remove 'The Adventures of Huckleberry Finn' because it uses the word 'nigger.' Some feel it's inappropriate for schools and want to replace it with books that say 'slave' instead. That would be a mistake because it diminishes the book's authenticity and effectiveness. The word's use in the book is powerful and thought-provoking. Replacing it with 'slave' weakens the passage's impact.  In conclusion, libraries should not remove 'offensive' books, music, or movies, because doing so would delete part of our history and knowledge. With everyone having different opinions on what is 'offensive,' it is difficult to tell which books to take out. Finally, doing so will not solve anything because people will still be mean, engage in sexual activities, use harsh language, and experience 'offensive' actions. That is the society we live in, and people will have to accept that fact. Therefore, we need to keep all the 'offensive' pieces we have, so people might be ready for the real world.

Katherine Paterson once said, 'All of us can think of a book that we hope none of our children or any other children have taken off the shelf. But if I have the right to remove that book from the shelf-that work I abhor-then so does everyone else. And then we have no books left on the shelf for any of us.' Katherine has a good view on the idea of censorship in libraries. Most books have ideas and topics that are offensive to one person or another. I believe that books that have something offensive in them should not be censored. An idea that is offensive to one person might not be offensive to the other, and vice versa. When authors write books they are pouring their hearts out to us. If someone thinks their book is offensive and it gets censored, the author of the book would be even more offended. Their life's work could go into one book and just because a group of people do not like it, it gets taken off the shelves. I don't know about you but I would rather read a book with an interesting and maybe controversial topic than a book that seems to go nowhere. If censorship in libraries actually happened, many authors might say forget it and not even write anymore. It is very hard to write a book that pleases everyone. Also, attraction to literature would seize. People are not attracted to books that do not have a quality topic that gets them interested. Literature would have an immediate downfall if books were censored. If books were censored, the quality of learning would not be the same. Books are tools for learning and taking them away would be harmful to education. Some teenagers including me might find some of the material they read-even in school-to be offensive or have a touchy subject. I do admit that reading books for class is somewhat annoying at times, but it will help us in the future. These books have meaning, which is why they are picked by teachers for students to read. Something offensive like a cuss word is not going to keep someone from finding the meaning of the book. The quality of learning would not be the same if books were censored. A book can be offensive, yes, but one book is not going to ruin someone's life. An important thing to remember is that by taking a book off a shelf, or not playing music because of a few harmful words is like denying the creativity and compassion of an author or artist. One book that is offensive to one, might not be to another. If books were censored, literature would have an immediate downfall and the quality of learning would not be the same. For all of these reasons, censorship in libraries should not be allowed, ensuring a wide range of perspectives and ideas remain accessible to all.

Recently the growing issue of censorship in libraries came to my attention. This is unfortunate in the extreme. People have a right to unmolested knowledge and censoring libraries is a direct violation of that right. Libraries are meant to be a place of learning and they should be kept that way.  History is filled with moments both glorious and inglorious. We aren't always proud of what we do or what happens, but those events remain, irrespective of whether or not we choose to acknowledge them. To think turning a blind eye to the less than clean will make it go away is not only unrealistic but also totally ignorant of facts.  I realize that there are some things children should not see or hear and I'm not suggesting we expose them to these things. I'm merely saying that trying to hide them from what we deem to be unclean is neither right nor a good idea in general. We can't shelter our children forever and sooner or later they will learn things we wish they didn't. This is inevitable. Life doesn't seek to hide its darker side from us at all and to hide it from our children will serve little more than to handicap them. Do children need to be protected for some things? Yes, for a time, they do, but it is the role of the individual parent to protect their child. Protect the children, but don't do so at the expense of everyone else.  Why should the views of some hinder all others? Those who would presume to know what people should see and what they should not are out of touch. Those prudish enough to believe that people need to be protected from natural things, from history, or from their own desires have no more right, and perhaps even less than everyone else, to interfere with individual decision making. People have a right to make their own choices on what they believe, but no right to force those opinions on others.  This essay, this month, may make no difference, but it has said what needed to be said and thus served its purpose. With that task completed, I can finish with a good conscience, knowing I've voiced my opposition to the dangerous trend of library censorship.

Many people base their actions on their own views. What some may appear to be justified in their minds, due to their beliefs, might cause an uproar from others. One instance of this: media censorship. It happens every day, every place. Someone can take it upon them selves to ,in their mind, 'make the piece better for public viewing'. In reality, though, they are really ruining the experience of the media for everyone else and even impeading on the rights granted to us by the constitiution: Freedom of the Press. First up, books in the library. Everytime I go to the library and pick up some books, there is always one book with the 'bad parts' marked out. Someone had found these words offensive and decided that no one should have to see or read them. To me, it was irritating. I don't always like those words either, but having them marked out is distracting from the page and , for me, ruins the author's voice and style of writing, hence impairing what I draw from the book. Some marked-out words aren't always offensive to others, either. Simply put, if you find the book offensive, don't read it. Others may enjoy it, whether they share your views or not. People also take the liberty of simply removing whole pieces of media from shelves just because they find it offensive. If everyone removed anything they didn't like, or found offensive, there would be nothing left in the world for anyone to enjoy. We, as American citizens, have the right to make our own choices, and our choices should not be limited by the views of certain individuals. That means that if I want to read or view something, it should be available to me, so I may learn and expand my views, even if it makes someone else uncomfortable. With nearly every disputable form of media that comes out, people harangue the producers and say the piece should have never been made. Wrong. Producers and authors can publish whatever they would like. It's called Freedom of the Press, and it is a right garunteed to us, as United States citizens, under the Constitution. And learly, if pieces like that are being produced, people read it. Plain and simple. You might not, but maybe a neighbor, or even a relative, may not be offended by it and might read it. Supply and demand. If everyone found it offensive, no one would buy or read it, and because of that, it would no longer be produced. You would get your way. But, no. Some people do read it and it is produced. Again, if you don't like it, don't read it. People should not take it upon themselves to censor what others can and can't do, see, or read. If someone wants to read a story that has 'bad words' in it, so be it. Others should not ruin the experience by marking the words out. Not only is it rude and ruining the experience for the reader, but it is also destroying someone else's property. If someone wants to view something that is against a certain religion, so be it. They have the right and no one can take that right away from them. In my opinion, censorship in libraries, whether by government, or other civilians, should not be allowed. We citizens are allowed the right to make our own choices and in public libraries, the public should be allowed to read or watch whatever they want. Choice is one of the prinicples of the constitution, and it should be protected, not limited.

Many libraries contain books, movies, music, and magazines that can be considered offensive. All of these libraries, however, have certain reasons to have these books. Whether those reasons are for education or for recreation, the libraries have reasons for them. So, the libraries that do have 'offensive' books, should be allowed to keep them because they are not offensive to everyone, and they could be beneficial to the reader. These books that are considered offensive to some people this month may not be offensive to others. For example, Sarah, who is from the South, comes into a library and finds a book that is all about the Civil War, and she reads that the South is full of a bunch of people who mistreated their slaves. Sarah gets a little offended by this. Then little John, who is an African American, picks up the same book and reads all about the South and how they treated their slaves. Little John thinks that the same book that Sarah hated is a great book. As shown in the example, America's people are very diverse, but what comes with that diversity is a lot of opposing views in its citizens. A library doesn't want to only appeal to one race, it wants to appeal to all of them, the only way to have that happen is to accidently offend some people in the process. The citizens of the United States need to be more understanding that their race isn't the only one here. If a book offends a person, that person simply should not read it. However, these books, who many this month find offensive, could also be beneficial to their readers. Some of these books could be helpful to the people who choose to read it. Going back to the Civil War reference, Sarah was reading her local Southern text book, and she read about the horrible deeds the South had done regarding their slaves and the fact that they lost the war to the Union, and she got offended because her side lost. Then little Timmy, who is in the same class as Sarah, was reading his history text book and was becoming more and more elated as he read on. He found out that kids all over the the country were learning about what had happened to his ancestors and that the Union defeated the South. Timmy was as happy as he could be with this book, whereas Sarah couldn't be any more displeased. If this book was pitched out of the library, how would students all over the nation learn of the Civil War? They wouldn't. Libraries cannot just throw out books because they offend someone. As Katherine Paterson said, if we all picked a pile of books that offend us and got rid of them, then there wouldn't be any books left for any of us to read because other nations would be offended by the books that appealed to one, and so on and so forth. So, libraries need to keep the books that they have and get even more books. This nation needs as many books as it can get because they are all extremely helpful to those that they appeal to. We just need to remember that not all of the books appeal to us and not to get offended by those that don't, ultimately allowing for a wider range of perspectives and knowledge to be accessible to all.

Katherine Paterson once said 'All of us can think of a book that we hope none of our children or any other children have taken off the shelf. And then we have no books left on the shelf for any of us.' So if they're taking books off the shelves because they find them offensive, then there will be so many books gone, that the kids will not have a broader view as so many people are lucky to have today. Maybe then people wouldn't be offended by it. Just because one person doesn't like it doesn't mean another wouldn't either, and restricting access based on subjective offense undermines individual choice and intellectual freedom.

Cooling the **passion**, **fervor** and **zeal** From Book **Banning**, Censorship in public libraries would be an insult to the institution. A library, a citadel of knowledge, should not be bound by a society as to what knowledge it can convey. One point of a library, the destination of researchers, is to offer information that must be sought: for those who cannot find the information in their homes without fear, for those who cannot ask their questions without retribution, the library stands as a pillar of safety. Books are incapable of judgment.  To censor the books held in a library is to chip away at human progress. A freedom of thought and a freedom of press, present within our nation and increasing in presence around the **globe**, precludes the idea of this censorship.  If any book is subject to criticism or opposition, are not all books worthy of the same? To value one opinion or perspective less than another is to debase the entire culture from which libraries have arisen. Libraries are a communal institution, open to all views and writings. The point of bringing books together under one roof is to equate them, and give them all equal standing as literature or scholarly works.  From personal experience, censorship in the library has cost me precious time, and has stolen from me parts of my life. Growing up in a small town, where ideas of gender and sexuality were somewhat firmly set, any search for dissenting opinion was often fruitless. When I visited my school's library, as a child searching for answers about my sexuality, I found little aid. Around the library were a thousand stories of a man and woman falling in love, but never did I find a fairy tale of two princes. It was not until I left the school that I found that such books did exist in my old school library, but kept removed, off the shelves, restricted. More insulting than finding books of **LGBTQ+** issues completely unrepresented was to find that they were treated so separately.  Here lies the problem. Some people believe that if minority opinions or values are unrepresented, they will disappear. Such is the point of censorship: ignoring an issue or a life-choice to the point of extinction. But books cannot shout their values. They cannot shove information down our throats. Books must be read, we must give our consent to their knowledge. Unlike an advertisement that might accost us unawares, we must pick up a book and open it to receive its guidance.  If my library had done its job and given me the guidance I sought, I would have grown so much more easily. I would have learned not only how to express and accept myself, but I might have grown to more easily accept others as well.  In the past few years, with the effects of **World War II** **and the Holocaust** **reaching their pinnacle** reaching the newest generation, **Germany** has searched for ways to pay homage to the victims of the violence of **Nazism** and of the **Third Reich**. What the country finds, however, is that it cannot effectively memorialize the tragedies. In trying construct a monument, the government and culture find that they have little to build off of. The products of murder and book-burning have resulted in an emptiness, a void. As such, architects have created what **could** be called 'anti-monuments', commemorating a void to posterity to memorialize what was lost. One of the most powerful, to me at least, appears in the form of a negative bookshelf: a solid wall, with gaping holes in the form of book spines, ranging across the rows. Such is the knowledge lost from book-burning. We cannot even describe what is lost, for the knowledge has vanished. We must ask, what are we missing? What views, what prose, what beauty has been taking from us while we continue living, never having the chance to glimpse it?  This is the effect of library censorship. To remove a book from its natural and rightful place on a shelf is to set its words aflame. Once it is gone, it will be forgotten. To protect our posterity, to enlighten our descendants, we must work to preserve all books, any book that appears offensive, or disgusting, or brave, or new. Let the reader decide its value. Let the person in search of answers pick it up or leave it behind. Give the book a chance for it **to** have a power that is unrealized. Leave the libraries as they are, as the monuments to the preservation and progression of knowledge and wisdom.

Censorship is a topic that is strongly opinionated. If one person does not like the content of a text, that person might find themselves saying that they have the right to abstain from being able to view that text in a library, public location, or online source. But what about the other people? Shouldn't they have a say too? Let's say that 'person one' does not agree with the language in a text, but 'person two' perhaps does. Which person has the benefit in **this** situation? Freedom of speech and expression are two factors that are very valued, and perhaps sometimes even overlooked in our society. In **this** case, both 'person one' and 'person two' are allowed to have a right to say and think what they feel about the text. Should 'person one' still have the right to say that **this** text does not belong in a public location? Well, if every person had the right to remove something that they disagreed with from the public, there nothing would be left. In such a large and diverse society, there is bound to be at least one person who does not agree with the content of a certain material of each and every lyric, magazine, book, and text that there is available. Some might say that **this** is unfair to that one group who does not agree with the content of a material. But how is that fair to the other group who actually do agree with that material? Freedom of speech and expression are still not being excluded from that group who does not agree with such material. That group is still allowed to speak their opinions and takes on that particular material, as well as the people who do agree with the material. Take iTunes for example. If there is a song that has language and/or content that could be considered disrespectful to a person, there is a red tag by the song that says: 'explicit.' **This** is an indicator that a person who could find foul language offensive, that such person should not buy that song. There is also the compromise. Quite often, if a song is tagged as 'explicit', there is usually an alternative of the same song. That same song is then tagged with a gray tag that states: 'clean.' A song being 'clean' simply means that the song is still the same, but the considered to be disrespectful content is removed, or removed and replaced with different words that are not considered to be disrespectful. Both parties are now satisfied with the so called: happy-median. Take movies as another example. Movies are rated based on their content. The higher the rating, the more explicit such movie is. Along with the rating, there is an explanation as to why that movie is rated the way that it is. If you are a person who is careful about viewing things that are against your own opinions and beliefs, then by seeing the rating and explanation, such person knows that **this** material is not for them. Again, the happy-median. For every given case of a group of people who do not agree with the terms of a certain content, the alternate group must be considered as well. Both parties in **this** case are still able to say and express their own opinions. So, should **this** context be removed from the eye of the public because a certain group of people do not agree with the content in it? No. However, one must keep in mind the views and opinions that each person has on such material, and that person should still be respected for their take on that material, even if we ultimately decide against censorship to uphold broader freedoms of expression.

I haven't personally encountered a book that was racially offensive to me or that I felt should be censored, but I did read a book with a lot of racism and sexual content. While I'm not racist, some individuals hold deeply prejudiced views. Some library books contain content unsuitable for all readers, yet access isn't always restricted. Certain books, movies, magazines, and other media might warrant reconsideration for removal to shield certain audiences.  Libraries often house books containing racist content. Some instances of racism in these books can be extreme, potentially intriguing young readers and leading them down a harmful path. This could result in them influencing their friends, promoting racist ideologies. Most parents wouldn't want their children to become racist, though some families do hold such beliefs, which is hard to understand since we are all the same.  Sexually explicit content is also present in some library books. Detailed descriptions can be inappropriate for young readers, potentially leading them to experiment prematurely. While such exploration is acceptable at an older age, exposing young children to such content is wrong, and many parents would object to their children reading such books. I know I wouldn't let my child read a book like that.  Music, a universal form of expression, also faces scrutiny. Some find rap music offensive and advocate for its removal. However, rap often reflects personal experiences and struggles. It can contain racist language and unsuitable content for young audiences.  Given the presence of potentially harmful content, such as racism and explicit material, perhaps these materials should be housed in a separate area accessible only to older individuals. While books with racism should still be available to show the past, this could protect younger readers from exposure. By segregating these materials, we could still provide access to these materials while safeguarding younger, more impressionable minds.

Having someone who does not work in the law or a person who is not a legal guardian or parent of someone who is not of age should not tell someone not to buy, read, or watch something just because it might be offensive or offend that one person. This respects individual liberty and free markets.  I conclude that in order for someone to tell another person not to buy or rent material that person would either have to be law enforcement or their legal guardian as long as they are not of age. Censorship, that's a word that causes a lot of arguments in today's society. People have extremely different views on censorship throughout the world. In some countries, dictators don't allow their citizens to have internet access, watch the news, or in some more extreme cases, even watch television at all. The majority of the time they do this because they don't want the citizens of their country to know what is happening around the world. This sets up a 'fish bowl' environment, meaning that people from other countries see all of the issues in that country, but the people actually in the country have no idea what's going on around them.  Although we don't always see censorship in that extreme of a sense, it still plays a large part in today's society. Everything from music on the radio to military files are censored. Think about it, how often can you listen to a song on the radio that all of the original words are still intact? Arguments over censorship have gone back and forth for years without really making much progress at all. Each side of the argument, whether it's for or against censorship, is almost entirely opinionative. No one can say for sure that censorship is completely needed or not. It's just too hard to determine who's opinion is really more convincing.  In my opinion, I don't think anything should be censored. If the writer of a TV show throws in a vulgar word, most likely it's for the effect that it has on people to show emotion. The same thing goes for songs, when an artist writes the lyrics to a song, they are trying to convey a message and they use certain words that get their point across more effectively or more dramatically. Parents argue that their children are seeing too much violence on TV and are causing behavior problems along with other things, and that shows need to be more suited for children. There is an alternative to censoring all of these things, rather than 'ruining' everyone's fun just don't let your kids watch that show.  In the USA today, we have something called freedom, we exercise this right everyday with what we wear, and what we say. I think that we should take that freedom and apply it to censorship. Instead of complaining about violence in movies and sex on TV, you can make a decision simply to not watch that kind of show. Everyone has the option to say NO; if you don't want to hear or see something simply choose something else to watch, or even just do something entirely different. You don't have to do anything that you don't want to do. It's is an easy solution, all you have to do is exercise a right that you have had since the day you were born and just say no, I don't want to do that. It's very simple and could potentially stop all debates on whether or not things need to be censored. Therefore, by taking personal responsibility and making individual choices, we can navigate the complexities of content consumption without resorting to broad censorship, ultimately preserving freedom of expression while protecting individual values.

Some books should remain in libraries, free from censorship, as past experiences show it can diminish a book's impact. For example, in the book @CAPS1 @NUM1, the burning of books leads to societal collapse. Recently, @CAPS2 @CAPS3 has faced censorship, primarily due to the word "nigar," deemed offensive by some, leading committees to consider its removal from school shelves. Katherine Paterson, a well-known author, presents an idea with which I strongly agree. She states, 'All of us can think of a book that we hope none of our children or any other children have taken off the shelf. But if I have the right to remove that book from the shelf--that work I abhor--then you also have exactly the same right and so does everyone else. And then we have no books left on the shelf left for any of us.' If everyone has the right to remove certain books that they find inappropriate, there **would** not be anything left for people to read. Although it is a good thing for parents to have a voice and stand up for what they believe, books should not be banned. Many people have different views on what is right and wrong. Some **might** suggest that a certain book is obscene, while others **may** be offended by a different book. If every parent had the right to get a book banned, there **would** come a time when no books meet the approval of the parent. Some of these books present great learning opportunities to students. Books often allow students to think in different, new ways. They can learn from a new point of view and broaden their understanding of the world. Often times, a student can look at his or her own morals and values, which is a good thing, and reflect on their own beliefs. If a teacher finds a book which they think is appropriate, parents should respect the decision of this teacher. They **can** suggest another reading, or offer other ideas, but to go as far as getting the book completely removed is not right. While removing books for reading **may** be going to far, things such as movies could go the other direction. Personally, my parents would be horrified to see grotesque, inappropriate movies set out in broad daylight where everyone can look at them. I think that this difference between books and movies is a simple thing: Books do not normally have an inappropriate cover, while bad movies often do. Because of this, even the people who do not wish to view the movie are often forced to see images which they find disturbing. If one was to walk past a book they did not intend to read, they do not have to be apalled at the cover as they pass. Although parents care about the things their children read, books should not be banned. Although other things **may** have affects on youth, books are a different story. They allow one's self to dive deep into thought, to make observations, and to form opinions. They are a key to growing, learning, and discovering; therefore, protecting access to a wide range of books is essential for fostering intellectual development.

I do like censorship laws to an extent. However, the government cannot ban everything that they deem inappropriate. I think it depends more on what the family deems inappropriate. I do not think they should have any completely inaccessible areas in libraries for children of younger ages, because this limits exposure to a variety of ideas. I believe that the viewer should have a family member's consent to view said content. I also believe that if the content is not relative to the viewers interests, then they should just not look at it. They are not required to look at it so if they do not like it, then they do not look at it.  However, if the library does not consent to holding the books, music, movies, magazines, etc., then they do not have to and the viewer can go somewhere else, as the library has the right to curate its collection based on its mission and community needs. And if they do have the books, music, etc., then they can put limits and ratings on them. But I do not think that an adult could go in and complain about inappropriate material. As I said before, if they do not like it, then they are not required to look at it.  I actually think that the government should not tolerate parents whining and complaining about the content of different materials. One parent should not have the ability to take away others' privileges to books, because they deem it inappropriate. Just because they do not like the content, does not exclude all others from enjoying it.  Also, if a library does have an age restriction on certain materials, then appropriate acts of discipline should be taken for the viewer of said materials. However, if the viewer has an adult family member with them and has their consent, then I think they should be able to view the material, regardless of ratings, as parental guidance should be prioritized. Ultimately, a balance must be struck that respects both individual freedom and community values regarding access to library materials.

The censorship of certain media is such a controversial topic. Whether a certain piece of material is considered offensive and should be censored or not is more often opinionated rather than logically opposed, because it really does all come down to someone's opinion on this matter. It is too difficult for most people to step in someone else's shoes or be persuaded from a viewpoint different from their own or even escape pressures from the general public to consider something else. Things get censored for a lot of reasons, too! Sometimes they're just so intentionally offensive that perhaps the author or producer wants it to be censored or would appreciate the controversy, or that a new view or opinion is so radical and against a majority of the population that it is just considered offensive for being so different. Well, when does someone have a right to take a song off the air or pull a book permanently from a shelf? The question becomes, at what point does public outcry warrant the removal of content?  The first thing that needs to be contemplated is if something is offensive or not. There are extremes to pieces of media where one sometimes must ask, "WHAT were they thinking when they made that?" A movie being so outrageously graphic or violent is a fine example (although the same thing can happen in books, just with words instead of pictures). At the same time though, whether or not something you might think as unnecessary gore in a film might just be WHAT I'm excited to see when I go to the cinema - it's all opinionated!  Another interesting thought is that somebody might come up with a revolutionary, radical scientific theory and write a whole novel or film a documentary explaining it all, but certain groups of people might claim that it is offensive to them. However, we might investigate into that theory ourselves and not be offended in the slightest. This is understandable though, people grow up in an environment that has its own set of ethics and principles, and people will honestly believe them and probably stick with those fundamentals throughout their lifetime. If you go against someone's beliefs that they hold so dear like that, they would of course be offensive to them. Does that mean that the something should be censored just because it offends a couple of groups in a population?  Whether or not something is to be torn from the access of the public is left up to the opinions of the general public themselves. The opinion of the public is created by the current time, trends, ethics, and problems that are going on. When something goes against too many of those things, people get upset. If most people are upset by something, it will probably start disappearing from sight. It's bad for business, and libraries are losing customers already due to most people not having an urge to read anymore with all of the stuff that you can do otherwise. Certain things can just put a bad taste in your mouth, and if someone gets that too often when they go to a library, they probably won't go there anymore.  So when it comes down to censorship in libraries, or anywhere, its just a bunch of opinions. If the general public does not like something, it will stop showing up. Certain books or other pieces of media are asking for the controversy that many subjects bring, while others are just unintentionally going against certain groups of people. People's beliefs are determined by where they grew up and when, and they'll hold on to those things for their lifetime. If something goes against those, people will be offended, and if enough people are upset, it gets taken away, demonstrating that censorship, at its core, is often a reflection of the prevailing sentiments and values of a society at a particular point in time.

For many students it is hard to compose essays in a public school's library. Acquiring the necessary information is comparable to finding a needle in a haystack. This is not due to the lack of funding or even the quality of teachers and staff. No, neither of these problems is the cause behind many students' inability to compose thought-provoking essays and analyses over a myriad of topics. This is due to the extremes in censorship that are being placed on libraries and schools in general. Many of the relevant topics and materials needed to truly understand our constantly changing world are being removed from the grasp of those who will go on to lead this new world. Some prime examples of this tyranny on knowledge is the removal of books such as *Huckleberry Finn*, *To Kill a Mockingbird*, the *Bible*, and many other classical works. Each of these, according to many parents, has good reason to be removed from our libraries. *Huckleberry Finn* promotes discrimination and racial supremacy along with being written by what some critics have pegged as one of humanity's most vile of creatures. *To Kill a Mockingbird* uses racial slurs that are not appropriate to be in the hands of our young children. The *Bible* violates the separation of church and state. Many other classical works reference racism, drugs, murder, sex and use rampant profanity. All of these are valid reasons as to why a parent might advocate for there to be censorship of our libraries. These reasons, as well meaning as they might be, are no longer good enough to be valid in today's changing environment. Many of the books that have been recommended to be removed show us an unfiltered view of a time period from a point of view that did not belong to the 'victor' of the social battle. As we know, 'history is written by the victors.' While it is good that the Union won the Civil War and helped abolish slavery it is still important to realize that we still cannot remove the viewpoint from our centers of knowledge. To forget is to remember at another time. That time is when we repeat the same mistakes again. For the parents who also want to save the innocence of their children by forbidding these books from libraries need to realize that the media has been pumping these forbidden images to their children more than books have. To censor our libraries is to cripple our children from the knowledge they need to fully understand our shadowed and fragmented world, and because of this we do our children a great disservice. Just because we try and close our eyes to the realities of the world does not mean that they don't exist; it is better to see and understand than to enter the world blind and dumb.

There are big debates today over whether or not certain materials, such as books, music, movies, magazines, etc., should be removed from the shelves of libraries if they are found offensive. Plenty of arguments are made from maybe somebody's own experience, observations, and/or reading. I have read plenty of people's concerns regarding this issue, and there are some valid points to be made from both sides of the story. No matter what your opinion on this issue is, there will always be someone who opposes it. You see censorship of offensive language on television, but here is my take on whether or not censorship should take an effect on books, music, movies, magazines, etc. The first point that I would like to make about censorship is that people all across the world have come in contact with something that they might have thought to be offensive. When kids are old enough to understand what other people are talking about, they will come in contact with things that they take in offense at some point in life. I know from my own personal experience that you will see things that people think should be censored. Although I come from a religious family who does not like to offend anyone, I am old enough to realize that not everything in life is going to work out your way all the time. When you honestly think about it, you cannot censor out things that you hear in person, so why censor things in certain materials? The second point I would like to make about censorship is that no matter how much you try to censor certain materials, people will still find a way to take things offensive. There are certain things in life that you cannot control, and being insulted or offended is one of them. Even the most popular man or woman on the planet has been offended at least once or twice. It isn't about trying to censor every little thing that might be offensive to some people. Maybe it is about the people learning to deal with a little criticism. 'All of us can think of a book that we hope none of our children or any other children have taken off the shelf. But if I have the right to remove that book from the shelf---that work i abhor---then you also have exactly the same right and so does everyone else. And then we have no books left on the shelf for any of us.' This is a quote from Katherine Paterson that makes a big statement. Almost every well-written book that you will find on the shelf has something that should be censored. What would those books be without those statements? To conclude this debate on censorship, plenty of arguments have been made about the views of censorship. Many observations, personal experiences, and/or readings have been done by many different people. Truth is, there will always be people who disagree on this subject, but that is just the way things are. We may never know who is actually right or wrong about this topic. We do know though, that judging form the previous points above, it is very unlikely that certain materials will be removed from the shelves if they are found offensive, suggesting that tolerance and critical engagement might be more effective approaches.

I do not believe that certain materials should be removed from the shelves if they are found offensive. If the world is left without certain materials there will be no creativity. Everyone will be forced to think the same thoughts if they can't learn about other thoughts that are portrayed to be offensive. No one can read about a topic that they are interested in if it is banned, this will cease creative thinking by not allowing people to think differently. In the process of deciding what books are offensive and which are not offensive, all books will eventually be eliminated. Certain topics aren't liked by everyone and, as Katherine Paterson says, '...if I have the right to remove that book... so does everyone else. Books play a multifaceted role in human life, serving purposes from education and entertainment to various other needs. However, some books contain content that some readers find offensive. The question arises: should these books be avoided, discarded, or even removed from shelves altogether? There are arguments against removing offensive material, including the idea that individuals should learn to discern and avoid harmful content, that perceptions of what is "bad" are subjective, and that even offensive material has a right to exist.  The subjective nature of offense is a key consideration. What one person finds objectionable, another might find acceptable or even necessary. For example, some may object to strong language in a book, while others believe it is crucial for portraying a character's intense emotions or creating a realistic narrative. Similarly, descriptions of violence, while disturbing to some, might be seen as necessary for conveying the full horror of a situation to others.  Furthermore, individuals are typically taught to recognize and avoid potentially offensive material. If a reader encounters content they find objectionable, they have the option to stop reading. Just as one wouldn't knowingly choose an @CAPS1-rated movie when seeking family entertainment, readers should exercise discretion when selecting books. Resources such as online reviews and recommendations from others can help readers make informed decisions about content they might find offensive.  Even if material is deemed offensive by some, removing it from shelves is problematic because it imposes one person's opinion on everyone. If someone needs a book, they would be unable to obtain it because of its removal. If materials were removed based on individual objections, a decline in available reading material would occur, as anyone could claim offense, potentially exaggerating their reaction.  Therefore, materials should not be removed simply because they are deemed offensive. If everyone were to label content as offensive, the literary landscape would become barren. Individuals should not have the power to dictate the removal of books, as personal spite could influence such decisions. Ultimately, the question remains: should potentially offensive materials be removed from shelves? Given the subjective nature of offense and the importance of individual choice, the answer is no; books should remain available, allowing readers to make their own informed decisions.

Their message might be that profanity is used too often or that the way that the next generation below them may turn for the worst, but it is not used to harm.  Music is a way that people can express their emotions without taking it out on the people that have hurt them or the people that they have hurt themselves. When someone uses profanity in a song, it is not specifically said at one person; it is used to say how bad they feel about what has happened to them that they need something to really show how they feel. Many people who hear these lyrics sang to them believe that the person is telling them that that really is how they feel when it's just a verse. Music should not be taken away because it is just words and they should not hurt someone, especially when it is only a way to express.  In movies, you see someone get shot, brutally murdered, or attacked, and it's already a horrible thing because someone died or because someone did not have a fair life. This violence shown on the screens in homes, movie theaters, and schools is shown to teach people what dangers are really out there; they are not shown to teach people other ways to severely injure another person although that is how people perceive them. Movies are about taking an idea and showing the world your idea; to show the world that this is what you are thinking and that this is how you feel about something.  To have this all taken away shows that the generations before us are scared of what it is that we can do when we are a whole or what we can be if we stand alone and say that we don't like something. Books, music and movies that are all based on something that is real should not be banned just because they show individuality; just because they have the decency to show us the truth in all the lies told to us by a higher person. These people most likely believe that there is a thing as a perfect life when there is not one, so when people show the way that things are, they get scared that their ideas of a perfect thing are ruined by those who know the truth. The censorship of only things that are truly vile should be censored, not the things that have nothing to do with the way that the communities are today, because it stifles creativity and the opportunity for diverse perspectives to be shared.

Certain materials, such as books, music, movies, or magazines, do not need to be removed from the shelves in libraries if they are found offensive. There are multiple reasons to back up this statement, including an accurate quote from author Katherine Paterson. People build their character through their reactions of how people treat them. For example, in life somebody might offend another person, but that does not mean the offender is going to disappear after doing so. How does this relate to libraries you might ask? Books and movies do not need to be taken off of shelves in libraries if they are found offensive because there are a lot of things in the real world that are offensive. It is your choice in what you want to read, listen to, or watch. Just because you might have the option of checking out something you do not think is appropriate or is offensive, does not mean you have to check it out. Some people might enjoy reading or watching things that are offensive. You might be wanting to argue, 'But I don't want my children being exposed to such offensive materials.' That is why most public libraries are split into children and adult sections. If you happen to come across an offensive book in the childrens section, then do not let your child check that out. It is as simple as that. Trying to take the book off the shelf or complaining about it would only take up more time. The quote, 'All of us can think of a book that we hope our children or any other children have taken off the shelf. But if I have the right to remove that book from the shelf-that work I abhor-then you also have exactly the same right and so does everybody else. And then we have no books left on the shelf for any of us', by Katherine Paterson, is a perfect example to conclude the reasons why books should not be taken off the shelf. She is saying that if one person is allowed to remove a book, then anybody else would be able to have that ability as well. Therefore, a book that might not offend you at all could be taken off the shelf because somebody else does not approve of it. Eventually, there would be no books left. In conclusion, if there are books, music, movies, or magazines that offend you, simply do not check them out. You do not need to get rid of them because somebody else might want to check them out.

Not everyone likes the same books, but every book in a library is there for a reason. The library screens all of the books that they get and wouldn't buy something if no one asked for it or if it wasn't a good book to have for their collection.  I think that everyone has a right to read what they like to read and that no one should have the right to take books off of shelves in a library because what if someone is looking for that book and the library is the only place that has it? Then where would people spend their time reading and enjoying the books that they have an interest in? If everyone could just pull a book off a shelf when they thought it was offensive there wouldn't be any books left on the shelves, and no one would have books to read. I also think that if you don't like the selection of books on the shelf that you shouldn't be looking in that section; go to another part of the library and look at the types of books that you like to read. There's something for everyone in a library, covering a wide range of topics and interests.  This is why I think it's not a good idea to be able to take books off of shelves; no one would have any books that they like to read if everyone did that when they saw something 'offensive', ultimately limiting access to diverse perspectives and knowledge.

Some books might be better suited for personal ownership rather than library lending, while others require a more mature understanding, like history books about sensitive topics or books with strong language. School libraries, especially at the elementary and high school levels, should curate their collections to match the age groups they serve, and librarians can guide younger readers away from inappropriate material. Similarly, music, magazines, and movies should be age-appropriate, as young children don't need exposure to excessive profanity. Libraries are often organized into sections for babies, toddlers, pre-teens, teens, and adults to help people find suitable material. If a teen finds a book in their section that seems more appropriate for adults, they should be able to inform a librarian. While individual sensitivities vary, libraries shouldn't remove every book that offends someone, as that would be unfair to others, especially since no one is forced to check out a particular book, so a balance between access and appropriateness is key.

This is what some parents might say to their child if they don't want them to read a certain kind of book or even a certain book. I feel that censorship is not needed in libraries, because either way, the kids will be exposed to something the parents don't want them to see sooner or later.  I do not believe that anyone has the right to remove anything from the shelves except the library. They can go ahead and complain that they don't want it there. But if the library has it, the library should be able to keep it there whether or not people don't want it there. I think the only real people that can remove a book from the shelves are the managers or manager if they agree with the patron. Other than those certain people, I don't think a regular person can remove anything from the shelves.  At the library I go to, they have any kind of book, music, movie, and magazine you want. Whether it is an adult content book to a rated R movie, they have anything, and they get new things every week. So if a person does not want a certain thing on the shelves they should not be able to by themselves take it from the shelves because what if another person wants to see the movie but they can't because a parent took it from the shelf because they did not want their kid being exposed to it. One time at my library I saw a verbal fight between a patron and the library manager; the patron did not want the book in the section it was in because they felt it was too provocative for a children's book. The manager refused to take it off the shelf because the library can have whatever books they want on their shelves. Another time I saw a person break a DVD because they thought children at the age their children were should not be allowed to see those kinds of movies. But breaking the movie is just putting other people that want to see it out because now they can't because it is broken.  To summarize everything, I do not think citizens should be allowed to remove anything from the shelves; only the managers of the library should be able to remove anything if they want, because ultimately, the library should be a place with access to a variety of information, and that access should not be dictated by individual patrons.

I think it's beneficial to have potentially inappropriate material available in stores or libraries because offensive content often attracts buyers. People who've experienced hardship might seek books reflecting their struggles, even if the content is offensive. My stance on censorship leans towards keeping offensive materials accessible because they are popular. Music, magazines, books, and movies can entertain adults and teenagers with their provocative content. Teens often adopt styles and behaviors from music, which can be a major source of this "inappropriate vibe."  Furthermore, offensive movies and television can be educational. Movies can offer life lessons or guidance, even within offensive contexts. Similarly, television shows, despite potentially inappropriate content, can teach viewers what to avoid. Books, a popular form of entertainment, often resonate with readers due to their relatable themes like personal reflections, struggles, love, humor, and drama. Readers may seek out offensive books to connect with shared experiences or gain insight into others' lives, or to be insightful of future career choices.  Magazines are the least offensive item on shelves, though I question their value due to their focus on gossip and misinformation, which ironically drives sales. While I believe magazines need improvement, offensive materials like music, movies, and books should remain accessible because they attract consumers, provoke thought, and offer potential learning experiences. In essence, the demand and potential benefits of these materials outweigh the concerns about their offensive nature.

The perception of what constitutes an offensive book is subjective. Determining whether content warrants removal from public access is complex, as sensitivities vary widely. While some material, particularly graphic or explicit content, might be deemed offensive by many, others may not share that view. Designating a separate section for potentially offensive items could be a compromise. Ultimately, complete removal is debatable, as items arguably have a right to exist on shelves. Parental guidance is crucial; policing content becomes a personal responsibility. It's for parents to set boundaries and decide what their children consume, instead of expecting institutions to universally censor material. If parents don't want their children exposed to certain content, the onus is on them to manage that exposure. Therefore, it's difficult for an outsider to dictate what is offensive and should be restricted, as individual values and parental control play a significant role in shaping exposure and perspectives.

Every book holds a potential meaning or message valuable to someone. Removing a book from a library diminishes access to knowledge for those who might need it. Disagreement with a book's views does not justify its removal. Books, regardless of potentially offensive content, should remain accessible. Both positive and negative perspectives should be available for interested readers. Music and movies, while potentially suitable, require careful consideration. Their inclusion in a library, traditionally a place of peace, should be contingent on maintaining a tranquil environment. While positive music and movies can offer comfort alongside reading, disruption warrants exclusion. Magazines present another challenge, often blending educational content with entertainment. Because many prioritize entertainment over education, their presence in a library is questionable. A library should prioritize learning, not entertainment. Removing books restricts potential knowledge, so books should remain accessible regardless of content. Music, movies, and magazines should have limited presence in libraries to ensure a learning environment.

I do not believe that movies, books, music, etc. should be removed from shelves. I believe that people are entitled to their own opinion about what they choose to listen to, read or watch, everybody has their own level of maturity. Parents who are concerned about their child watching/reading something, always have the right to tell them no, and to keep whatever it is out of their grasp. Whether it is books, movies or music, a person always has the choice of whether or not they want to be in contact with that item, making the decision personal. It is a good idea to keep more explicit things only for adults, but if it is supposed to be for a certain age level, it should be out for the choice to be up to that certain person. Different people have different levels of maturity, so it is hard for one person or company to say what age level should or should not be using that material. A lot of parents will disagree with this issue, because they think that children should be kept away from the violence and vulgar images or language that are in the media these days. But at the same time, they fight for the right to raise their child the way they want to. People have the right to take away material that is too mature for their child, but no one should be able to say that someone else's child should not be able to view that material, because just because one person finds it offensive, does not mean that other people will. If someone should find something offensive they should have the common sense to not view that material any more, it's that simple. Everyone has that right so I do not think that companies have the right to take that away from them. Parents can censor what their children watch, and adults have the ability to make their own decisions about this topic and what they consume. This proves that certain items, like books, movies, and music, should not be taken off the shelf, as the choice ultimately belongs to the individual and their family.

I personally don't believe they should use censorship in libraries. I feel as though no one has the right to say people are or aren't allowed to enjoy certain material just because someone thinks that it is offensive because that's just one person's opinion. What's one man's trash is another man's gold; what one person finds offensive could be sought out by millions. Plus, in today's world, if everything was censored, there would be nothing left, not even church, because everyone has their own opinion and their own belief, which would eventually eliminate everything because there will always be at least one person who thinks something is offensive in some way, shape, or form. If everything was censored, people wouldn't even be able to express themselves. If censorship was used everywhere, schools wouldn't be able to teach half of the material they teach today, and kids would have nothing to be involved in. Author Katherine Paterson once said, "All of us can think of a book that we hope none of our children or any other children have taken off the shelf. But if I have the right to remove that book from the shelfthat work I abhorthen you also have exactly the same right, and so does everyone else. And then we have no books left on the shelf for any of us." I, for one, completely agree with this quote. It's true, as I have already stated, if everything was censored, there'd be nothing left to be enjoyed. Think about it this way: would you like someone telling you that you're not allowed to read or listen to certain material just because someone felt as though it was offensive and thought it should be taken away from the public? I'm pretty sure that would make most people upset, especially if they're an adult. I feel as though everyone has the right to choose what they read and listen to; such freedoms are essential to intellectual growth. So, if you ever get asked if censorship in libraries should be allowed, then think back to everything I've said before you give your answer. Once they start censoring what everyone can read and listen to, then they'll feel as though they can censor any and everything and control people's lives, ultimately diminishing individual autonomy.

Throughout the world, there are thousands of people with various opinions. If one person thinks an art piece looks unique, another may not see any true beauty. But when people hardly understand the concept of other people, they should not be exposed to books or movies that could be defined as offensive. Some people don't know what it is like to be truly offended. When I was in middle school, I was a shy, fragile, young girl. I had just moved to a new school and was petrified of my new surroundings. For the first couple of weeks, I felt like an outcast; like an outsider looking in. I didn't fit in with anyones' group. Everyone seemed to of already have friends for years and here I was, a new student with no friends to communicate with. I was isolated and was desperately trying to find someone to be my friend. I wondered if something was wrong with me; if I has a bad odor or was dressed in an out of style fashion. I tried buying new clothes and changing my hair color. It seemed as if I wasn't even noticed. Before I knew it, school was half way over. I was still a nobody. Then David came along and made me a somebody. David, who had just moved to my school, looked bold and confident. At first, people waved a friendly hello but nothing more. As I sat at my empty lunch table, David approached me and asked to sit down. I couldn't refuse the offer so I nodded a sincere yes. The entire lunch period, we sat talking. We had a lot in common and I was glad to have made a friendship with David. Months went by before I realized David and I were great friends. I knew I could trust him with all of my secrets. Even though David and I were close, I felt as though he was always hiding something. Occasionally I would have enough courage to ask if there was anything he needed to tell me, but as the same as every answer before, it was a no. David and I had always walked to my house after school. But on one afternoon, something felt wrong. The air seemed to linger for miles. We didn't talk until we got inside my house. Suddenly David spoke and said, 'Why are people so cruel?' I was shocked by this question for I didn't know how to respond. David sensed that I had no clue what he was talking about so he continued. 'I'm gay.' I was appalled. Not because he was gay, but because he had never told me. I asked, 'What happened?' He sat on the couch then and told me about how he was in the library overhearing some of our classmates reading a book about people making fun of gays'. I felt awful for David. It wasn't his fault he was gay. I believe that certain books, movies, or music that are offensive to people should not be allowed on shelves. Some have never been offended. Some always offend people for many reasons. Everyone has feelings and it hurts when they are offended. We, as a community, should love one another and respect them, not read or listen to things that can hurt someones' inner feelings, thus creating a more supportive and understanding society.

I say influence, because studies and personal views have shown that teens and even young children are often influenced by explicit views portrayed by media. These children act in ways that reflect what they have seen. If they watch a movie full of violence, they often feel it is their job to act in violent manners. Until they reach an age of maturity and responsibility to make their own decisions, they let the outside world decide what is best.  As a child grows up, they are obligated to follow certain rules or take authoritative matters seriously. Authority teaches us, as children. We develop through our teachings and grow through our surroundings. You may ask what it is I am speaking about. Well, I believe that this situation relates to the phrase 'think before you speak' because it seems that the people displaying this media don't think about the after effects of their actions.  Suggest that certain material may not only be impacting children and teens, but adults are highly affected as well. I am not speaking as though everyone who watches a movie or reads a book about a murderer will go out killing people. I am only saying that our surroundings almost make us who we are along with the way we were raised. The media gives us insight and ideas, in which sometimes revolve around our every thought.  I do believe that certain media, should be displayed in confidential locations. If not, then it should be a recommendation and obligation to have an age limit. My concern for public media display pertains to the concern of the impact on human lives. As many would agree, censorship is a growing topic of concern throughout the world. I personally feel that censorship is necessary to a certain extent. If one feels the content of music, a movie, or a book is questionable, he or she has the option of reading, listening, or watching. Among many debated materials, movies have ratings, just as music has 'bleeps'. Movies are rated 'G' for all audiences, 'PG' standing for parental guidence, 'PG13' for parental guidence for ages 13 and older, and lastly 'R' meaning that anyone under the age of 17 is either suggested or required to have an adult present during the viewing of the film. At home, the ratings are all based on the parent's preference. At the movie theatre, the restrictions become a sort of law. Anyone below the age of thirteen is not permitted to see a movie that is 'PG13' or 'R' unless accompanied by an adult (anyone 25 or older). Anyone who isn't 17 or older cannot enter a movie rated 'R' unless accompanied by someone 21 or older. Depending on where you are, the restrictions can be more or less harsh. Ultimately, the rating system is intended to force parents to choose what is and isn't appropriate for their child. As for music on the radio, all 'curse words' are 'bleeped' out. If a person wants to buy their own music, artists are required to make two of the same album, one with censors and one without. Thus creating a decision usually for the parents, usually assuming they are the ones to but the album or the music for their child. When it comes to books, there are no ratings, just genres letting the reader know who the author's intended audience is. Types of genres include 'adult', 'young adult' and 'children' sections in libraries and book stores. Just like music and television, the final choice in the purchase is all dependent on the parents. Even though many restrictions put in place, there are still some faults to the system. Obviously if you are 13 or younger, you most likely won't have identification. This leaves the person working at the movie theatre the option to let in who they believe to be of age. Looks can be decieving. Buying music from the internet doesn't require any type of identification either. How can they prove your age? When purchasing a book, not many cashieers would stop a child and say, 'that's innappropriate for you'. Maybe kids of all ages should have identification. Although these are all underlying problems in the censorship system, it seems to all lead back to the parents. Censorship is a huge topic of discussion for the parents of today's young and growing society, but in reality, if they have an issue with the content, they themselves will either rid of the material or prohibit the use and or puchase of it. All in all, it's about the parents and their personal preference.

I often encounter books and magazines that I wouldn't want children to read daily, noticing inappropriate language or content in various forms of media. The same applies to conversations overheard in public. Because of this, I believe libraries should carefully consider the accessibility of such materials to children, as it's a public space. A child encountering disturbing content could potentially experience nightmares or be exposed to harmful information about crime or other wrongdoings.  Children might mimic or act out what they read, potentially normalizing negative behaviors. Exposure to inappropriate language, which is commonly heard, can lead to children repeating it without understanding the context or source. The availability of movies with mature themes, even the covers, could expose children to frightening or drug-related imagery.  Despite the prevalence of such content, public libraries should not be a source of exposure for children. Removing books and movies that depict crime, drugs, or other inappropriate content from shelves is crucial for protecting children, ensuring a safe and suitable environment for young readers. Therefore, removing those books and movies would be beneficial to children and their development.

The library might be the only way someone can get ahold of something they like; it provides access to diverse forms of entertainment. Kids might need the material that is offensive, it could help them through life. Exposure to challenging content can foster critical thinking skills. Other offensive material some adults enjoy reading or watching. Just because one person finds something offensive does not mean the next person that comes in will, and restricting access based on individual sensitivities can lead to a slippery slope of censorship.

No one should be alowed to tell you that you can't write a book as you want to write it. If we start censoring books, writers will be forced to censor their personal thoughts, limiting their creativity and expression. Making writers do that, limits thier freedom of speech.
